title: Sign Of 'Return Of Normalcy'? Postpaid Mobile Services Set To Resume In Kashmir From Monday

Sign Of 'Return Of Normalcy'? Postpaid Mobile Services Set To Resume In Kashmir From Monday

Sign Of 'Return Of Normalcy'? Postpaid Mobile Services Set To Resume In Kashmir From Monday

Seventy days after they were cut off from the rest of the world, Jammu and Kashmir is all set to be out from the communication blackout.

The Jammu and Kashmir government has confirmed that all postpaid mobile phone services will be resumed from Monday noon.

AP

The services were likely to be resumed on Saturday but a last-minute technical hitch led to deferring of the resumption of services. The subscribers will have to, however, wait for some more time for Internet services to resume in the Valley.

The government move comes as a welcome relief for the millions of Kashmiris who were living under a virtual blackout due to the suspension of telecommunication lines.

This was particularly harsh for those who were unwell and had family members living outside who could not get in touch with them.

Telephone, mobile and internet communication in the valley were snapped ahead of the surprise announcement on August 5, through which Article 370 which gave special status to the state was revoked. Even while they came under heavy international criticism for the communication blackout the government had insisted that it will be restored in a phased manner.

Earlier, fixed-line telephony was resumed in the valley on August 17, and by September 4 all landlines were declared operational.

AFP

The announcement about the resumption of mobile communication came just days after a travel advisory for tourists was lifted. The advisory was issued ahead of the August 5th announcement, citing credible security threats.

The restrictions on travel have harmed the tourism sector of the state, which depends on both domestic and foreign tourists who visit the valley in their thousands every year.
